--- title: "Ridge Regression" author: "Pierre Casadebaig" date: "2023-10-01" categories: [plotter] image: "img/preview.jpg" format: html: toc: true toc-location: left code-link: true filters: - lightbox lightbox: auto --- > ### Plotted postcards made by stitching together random fragments of the Pyrénées mountain range. Ridge regression is a tour of imagined landscapes pieced together from fragments of South-West France's diverse regions. We used digital elevation data to generate this collection, stitching together parts of different landscapes to create scenes that don't exist in reality but could have if nature had followed a different blueprint. ## Aims and inspiration Evolving from the [*dispyr*](/posts/process/dispyr) algorithm, where landscapes resulted from topographical data, this project explores the creation of imaginative drawings of landscapes. This project transforms data describing land elevations into aesthetic lines and shapes that resemble landscapes. On the physical side, our aim was to lend a more organic feel to pen-plotter renderings. This was achieved not just through coding techniques like line overlays and noise but also with tools including brushes, calligraphic pens, and technical pens. Below are few artworks that really stopped me in my tracks on the design of this project. I was particularly looking for early landscapes representations straying away from nature imitation.

([source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eight_Views_of_%C5%8Cmi#/media/File:Suzuki_Harunobu_(c._1760)_%C5%8Cmi_Hakkei_no_Uchi_-_Ishiyama_Sh%C5%ABgetsu.jpg)) ## Methods ### From Data to Landscapes We start with high-resolution data from digital elevation models that represents the variations in land height in South-West France. This data is transformed into a series of lines that we call "elevation profiles". These lines can represent anything from the horizon to a series of layered ridges, depending on where the data is sampled and how it's oriented. Working with this library of about 3000 profiles, we discard the less interesting ones and classify the remaining into two categories: flat ones that look like fields or plains, and tall ones that resemble mountains or high hills. To create the final piece of landscape, we select a random mixture of profiles — most are flat, but few are tall — and layer them accordingly. ### Organizing the Artwork The different landscapes generated by this process are organized into a catalog. Each page of the catalog is divided into different sections, or "cells", by a generative grid system. Each cell might contain a part of a landscape, a cloud, or even texts that look like writing but don't have a specific meaning. A grid system helps us divide the page space into different sized sections, both regular and irregular proportions. We do this by splitting the space into fractions, with each division being a one-sixth multiple. At the end, we designed four page styles ranging from full-page landscapes with different physical rendering (ink brush, technical ink pen) to figure-like gridded layouts with or without legend. ## Selected iterations
